story:
Short Summary

Hey everyone, my name is Cohen DeYoung. I decided about a year ago to start looking into screen printing and see what it is all about. Needless to say, I fell in love with it, and completely taught myself the basic ins-and-outs of the profession with only the help of the Internet and YouTube. I've definitely found my dream job. I started printing shirts for the band that I'm in and slowly started to print shirts for other bands as well. I want to make the big jump and make this a full time profession for myself.

Recently, I've started to get a lot of business, and I do have a decent little setup that I've funded myself up until now. The problem is, my equipment is not the best for producing mass quantities of shirts at a fast pace. The equipment gets too hot after a little bit of time, and it takes longer for me to cool down the equipment and shirts while printing than it actually does to create the shirt. This means it takes quite a bit of time to produce good quality prints with everything I have right now. Each print I have is created manually. I do have a day job as well (pest control), and so immediately after a full day of working outside, there I am in my humble little shop printing shirts until 2 in the morning. I then wake up at 6:30am for my day job, and repeat it all over again. I'm burning the candle at both ends, so to speak.

I like to keep my prices low for the printing and I have a lot of equipment upgrades that I'd like to get, but this is the main one that I need right now and the most expensive piece. I'm trying to get a new printing press that will not heat up as quickly and allow the shirts on the press to cool down, and make it possible to print more colors at a faster pace. All other upgrades I will be getting will be self funded.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The press I am trying to get is called a Vastex v2000hd 6/6. It is a manual press that will allow me to print up to six colors on a shirt, and has six shirt stations (this allows me to print five other shirts between the time that the first shirt goes under the flash dryer to become super heated to cure the ink, before coming back around for another color, giving the shirt and the equipment holding the shirt time to cool). This thing has a 25 year warranty and is built to last. It will probably be the only manual press I will need for the rest of my screen printing career. I've done my research, and this by far is the best press for the money.

I have some pretty cool perks for those of you that will help, please check it out!

 

The Impact

It's simple, you guys are helping one person's dream become a reality. I have always wanted to become my own boss. I've taught myself a trade and I'm learning more and more every day. This has become a true passion of mine and I plan on doing this for the rest of my life. Everyone wants to find that job they can actually enjoy doing each and every day while still feeling a sense of pride an accomplishment doing it, and this is it for me. You guys will be helping one new entrepreneur achieve his dream.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand some people aren't able to contribute. That's okay, you can still help!

Please share this with your friends to help get the word out there, and check out my facebook page! 

www.facebook.com/pulsemerch

 

Thank you so much for your time!

story:
East Nashville Radio

East Nashville is known for it's unique style of music and great venues. It is only fitting that there be a radio station representing it's cool vibe. Not only does ENR promote music created in East Nashville, but also Americana Roots nationwide and beyond. ENR is an online radio station broadcasting worldwide. Our audience is global! 

Our goal is to keep the airways filled with great music, eliminating on-air ads, giving indie artists an outlet for their music. When you go to our player at http://www.eastnashvilleradio.com it automatically starts. You do not have to fill out any forms or pay a membership fee. We want our audience to have an enjoyable listening experience on your computer at home, work or on the go with our FREE Android and iPhone app.

East Nashville Radio is the brainchild of Tommy Jenkins and Richard E. Carpenter. Seeing the vision, recording artist Eric Heatherly partnered in the ENR venture. Doug and Telisha Williams of Wild Ponies joined with their popular weekly series "Whiskey Wednesday". Soon to follow was the beautiful and sassy Chelle Rose bringing her monthly show 'Appalachian Rock N Roll'. Coming soon will be an exciting new show by Tommy Womack! We have great plans for the future and hope you will support us in this exciting journey.

In order to provide this great service we have to run fundraiser campaigns periodically. This will help pay our expenses & performance rights fees. We feel this is a better way as opposed to charging a subscription fee. If you enjoy East Nashville Radio please help us by giving to our fundraiser. We Need You! 

Thank you for your support,

Richard E. Carpenter

story:
FIRST OF ALL -- Thank you for taking the time to see what's going on here in my little corner of Indiegogo. I've created this campaign because Lyssa is hoping to be admitted for treatment at Cedar Springs Austin, this weekend (January 16th). Her body is on the verge of giving out completely, but her spirit is tenacious and I refuse to sit idly by as she conquers this monster named: Eating Disorder. 

For 3 years an eating disorder has controlled every moment of my life; from sun up to sun down and every second in between. Food is my enemy, my nemesis, and ignoring it is my comfort. 

Journeying through the reality of what caused this, acknowledging the truth/lies, and learning to eat again, to be free again, to live again has begun. This is my story, learning to live on, even in the moment when Reality Bites.

I just want to know this gets better. 
I just need to know the voices eventually go away. 
I just need to know the numbers don’t always matter and one day the calories won’t count themselves in my brain. 
I need to know that it’s possible to have my life back, because right now I don’t see one past my eating disorder, and I can’t live in the midst of this anymore.

The above is an excerpt from Lyssa's Blog. Since our Divine Introduction into one another's lives seven years ago, my admiration and love for Lyssa has grown exponentially. She is strong, intelligent, ambitious, and full of love. She has dedicated her life to serving others as a Missionary, an Upwards Basketball Coach, a Nanny, and a 6th Grade Teacher.  Her resilience in this wondrous and wearisome gift called Life astounds me again and again. 


Waiting and Ready for Liberation. 
Grasping at a Breakthrough.
Selfless, Impervious. 


These are words that describe our friend Lyssa. Let's show her what her life is worth ----- She is desperate to receive intensive treatment to end her battle with this life threatening illness, but she needs our financial support to make it happen.

She needs $5,500 for the treatment (to start) and another $1,200 to cover her financial obligations while she is reclaiming her life. If you are interested in the details of the program she will be benefitting from, they can be found on the Cedar Springs website here. 

Any amount of support you can offer will be sown directly into saving her life, and sustaining the joy of hundreds of people who cherish who she is in this world.

story:
Help a new and upcoming comic site shine! Wexlers Comics wants to be THE place for all your new and back issue needs; as well as supplies, displays, and other memorabilia. Our current stock of over 2500 books ranges from the 70’s to present-day! We are also looking for new sources for all your needs and would like to become your one stop shop for Indie Comics. However, advertising and site fees are currently preventing that dream from taking shape. Ideally, we would like to be able to fund our site for at least a year, improve our product line, and allow for quality advertising to show the great potential in our product. Two weeks ago, we successfully attended our first, small local comic convention here in the Chicago land area.  In addition, we were honored to have been asked to be part of one of the newest big conventions in Chicago land in June.

Bringing you the best Indie Books on the market is one of our main goals. We recently have found three up and coming local Indie companies and, as we grow, so will our list. We will be reviewing these innovative new books from artwork to plot to everything in between. These partnerships may even bring out new storylines as great minds combine. So if you are in to Indie, we want to be your one stop shop.

Currently, all funding for the conventions and website are coming out of my own pocket. Ideally, I would like to find like-minded folks interested in how far we can take our dream. So, in order to make all this happen we have turned to our peers (Yes, that’d be you!). 

Your funding will provide for the following:

  1. Site maintenance and growth for one year.
  2. Add more products to our store to fill your short boxes, walls, or shelves with all your favorite super heroes, along with the hard to find Indie books that we all love.
  3. We are working with a T-Shirt company to try and get shirts available at the low cost of 5 dollars a shirt, exclusively available on only two sites.
  4. The lowest priced books available. All of our books are priced well below market value of the grade that we give them. We use the CPG standard in our grading to give you the best possible price. Some even say we grade harder than the CPG standard.

In the future we will provide some of the best prints, at great prices, in addition to hard to find variants, autographed books, and even foreign issues.

Our site currently features three up and coming bloggers. Taryn works on comic book movies while Jeff comments on industry trends. Taryn, our movie critic, was involved in the Hollywood scene for many years and has a deep understanding and love of movies; while, Jeff, our comic book guru, has been studying the comic world for over 20 years. I will, personally, be providing you with reviews of every Indie book our site features.

I have been involved in the retail business for over 10 years and take pride in the fact that customer service will drive our company. It became clear that there was a hole in the comic book industry when it took me three weeks to speak to a company that I had ordered from and then another 2 weeks to receive my items. We want to get to a point where we can take any order to find certain books. Consistent networking and attending 3 to 6 conventions a year will expedite the search for that special book you have been seeking. Strong relationships with a variety of sources are being forged to allow for easy search and finding that one book that continues to elude you.

We understand that you are taking a leap of faith by contributing to our cause, so every contributor will receive something in return. Below you can see what is available for each pledge. We plan on having all items shipped no later than June 30th unless we have some draw backs. This should not be an issue as all Items are currently instock.

Even if you cannot contribute today (the day that you first find us), please check out our website and like us on FaceBook. Also, if you can please share this with your friends and family and contacts on Facebook. This way you can keep track of what we have going on and where we are going. 

So, if you can, please give what you can today and help out our cause. Be a part of new and fresh ideas that we feel will fill a new niche in our industry and fill your boxes with a ton of great books at great prices. So remember that any pledge that you submit guarantees you the item listed below. And you never know, if we are very successful, we may be able to add more as this drive continues. So stay tuned!!!

============================================================

Goals to help drive

*$500 (Not Reached) - One Copy of Imaginary Places by Black Heart Comics Signed by Chris Sweeney for Pledges of $40 or more.

*$1000 (Not Reached) - One Copy of The Infinium by Tango Unlimited Signed by Rich Perez for Pledges of $40 or more.

*$1500 (Not Reached) - 3 Random books added to Pledges of $10 or more.

story:
My name is Jason Palmer and I am now a runner. I used to hate running, probably because I was forced to do it in school, but now that I choose to run, I find that I love it. On March 17th, 2013, I will be putting my joy of running to the test as I attempt my very first marathon. But I’m not Forest Gump and I didn’t just "start running…" I’m running for a cause.

There is an amazing church in Santa Monica called Risen Church. For over 10 years I was looking for a place to call "home" and I found it here. It is unlike any other church I've been to, and part of that is because of the community found there. But more importantly, it strives to "make disciples of Jesus who will join God in the restoration of all things." This may sound like wild, religious talk, but it's not. It basically means that we want to see more love in this world... the really good kind of love.

Risen Church is trying to become independent and do awesome things in the city of Santa Monica. But [spoiler alert] we need a lot of money in order to become independent – I guess even churches have to pay rent and health insurance and stuff.

So I thought: What if I ran a marathon as a way to help support my church? After all, Risen needs to raise over $100,000 and that’s a HUGE endeavor… almost as huge as running 26.2 miles! 

Many people run races for various causes and charities, and I’ve chosen to run for my church. If you have a few extra bucks, I’d be grateful if you’d support me in my quest to conquer the LA Marathon next month. Your contribution will not only help me remain focused and motivated, but will also help ensure that our small, little “ragamuffin” church can keep its doors open and continue helping people. Plus, all of your donation will go directly to Risen's fundraising campaign: Rise Up! Huzzah!

My goal may seem a little high (at least it does to me), but I like to aim for the moon. I’d love to raise $2,620, which is $100 per mile (not that you have to donate that much, though I'd kiss ya if you did). And if you're thinking, "$100 per mile sounds ridiculous", well, just think about running 26.2 miles. Now THAT'S ridiculous!

A few bucks go a LONG way, so even $5 or $10 would be greatnly appreciated. And if you're like my family and are shocked that I'll be running that many miles, then please throw down a little extra. Again, it's ALL going to a wonderful cause!

Thanks in advance for helping me find the courage to do the insane and for your support in ensuring that Risen Church can continue to do incredible things. And take heart in knowing that when a short, crazy-haired, young man (me) crosses the Finish Line, it will largely be because of YOUR support. :)

story:
The History, the Project and the Problem

Jasmine's childhood was as rough as they come, gowing up in a poor, rural Cambodian village.  She had no dad, she scavenged rubbish for a living as a four-year-old, she was chased out of roadside shack-restaurants for trying to scavenge food, pot-bellied with malnutrition.  She nursed her beloved mother to a death from AIDS, sometimes finding her in her own defecation and covered in ants.  She was sold off as an orphan to be used as a pre-pubescent sex toy.  It all went down hill from there.

Owen was born in Daru, an island off Papua New Guinea and raised in Perth, Australia.  He had a rural-urban middle-class upbringing, and has always been something of an artist-come-eccentric, affectionately referred to in one review as "a real life eco-Willy Wonka".  His projects have often involved community and social responsibility in one way or another, whether it be with Aboriginal Australians, victims of the devastating Boxing-Day-Tsunami in Aceh, or poor Cambodians. 

Owen and Jasmine married in 2008, and were working towards one day building an eco-resort that would not only be a wonderful place to live, but would also benefit poor Cambodians. They didn't have enough cash yet, and Owen had been offered a well-paid job if he had an English teaching certificate so went to Phuket to train for a couple of weeks.  While there he met an old man who was also there looking for a change of career.  Owen looked out for him, and they spent quite a bit of the ‘spare time’ together during the course. About a week in, the old guy asked Owen if he had any ideas for a project that might be good for some poor Cambodians, and he told him about the Jasmine Valley project, which he was working towards. The old fellow offered to finance it so it could happen more quickly – an offer Owen initially turned down because the risk of business in Cambodia is high, and it would be crazy to borrow for such a project. The old guy insisted that this wasn’t a ‘loan’ as such, but that Owen should reinvest everything back into the project for the first years, then only pay him back if he’s still alive when Jasmine Valley is making good money.

This all seemed too good to be true, but the old guy assured Owen there were many rich Americans looking for philanthropic opportunities; people who didn’t want to “just will their money to the university”. He said he had already given his sons houses and they didn’t need any more money. He also said that he’d lost a million dollars in the Global Financial Crisis, and would prefer to risk losing money on a project that would be good for people in need.

So, they agreed. Owen asked that they put things in writing, and the old man insisted it be a gentleman’s agreement, and that we just shake hands. With that, Owen shook his hand and promised he would do his best, but that was all he could promise.

As things panned out, Owen received an inheritance and sold his house, all of which he committed to the project, so with the combined moneys and a great deal of very hard work Owen and Jasmine built an eco-resort that is currently still functioning as a social enterprise helping young, very undereducated, very poor Cambodians.

As time ticked by and the old guy spent extended periods of time in Cambodia, it became clear that he very much enjoyed the company of 'the ladies', and he consistently asked to be taken a small disco that was running in town during his first visit. These places are where one can pay a couple of dollars to a cute 16 year old girl and she’ll sit on your lap for a couple of hours – not an appropriate place for them to take the old man, whether he wanted girls to sit on his lap or not, especially given that they were a small family-oriented business in a small down.  There was then a complaint about sexual harassment from an employee of the old man’s – he had decided to set up his own project and had one young Cambodian woman working for him by then.

Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort is a family friendly resort. Many of the clients are NGO workers fighting the child-sex-trade in Cambodia. Others are missionaries and the like. It was very problematic, and once they had what they considered a serious complaint, Owen was professionally and ethically obliged to raise it with the old man. If he didn’t, Jasmine Valley (and Owen and Jasmine personally) would have likely gained a very unsavoury reputation, as Kep, and even Cambodia, is a very small community. It could well have destroyed them.

They felt very conflicted because of their financial relationship with the old man and their duty to confront him, but Owen raised the complaint with him and he became very angry. He then proceeded to meet with Owen's colleagues and their families to tell them that Owen had stolen his money and intended to steal more. Nothing could be further from the truth, but it seems he had successfully convinced himself of things he needed to believe in order to begin making real trouble for Owen and Jasmine. 

And there was trouble.

To cut a long story short, the old man has demanded that Owen and Jasmine return his money, plus 12% pa interest. Of course, they didn’t have the financial resources to do that, because it had all been used to create Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort.  They have made several offers in good faith to give him the money back over time, but he has refused all offers and has taken them to court in a country where ‘money talks’. He would be laughed out of court in America or Australia. He has asked the court to sell everything Jasmine and Owen own and give him the money. Incidentally, the old man recently made an offer outside the court. It would have been very difficult for them to service, but they accepted nevertheless in order to stop this ridiculous conflict. He then retracted his offer, for no apparent reason, as they walked into the court. It appears to be a game for him.

The court has made the decision that Owen and Jasmine will have to pay the old man $230,000 (about $40,000 more than the actual amount, since he submitted to the court a bank transfer from himself to himself, saying it was as a transfer to Owen - bizarre!) by March 2012 or have their property auctioned off.  Owen and Jasmine will appeal, but the net result, should they eventually go through the whole court system, and should the high court eventually decide to grant the old man his wish, would be that Jasmine and Owen, and their children, lose everything they own. 

In good faith, Jasmine and Owen have made the old man offers to pay him out over time, but he refuses anything that’s actually doable. They have also offered to sell Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort and give him his money, but the old man has put an injunction on the property to it can't be sold.

Our fundraiser is a desperate attempt to raise the money needed to move the old man on.  To save Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort.  We don't feel great about fundraising for something 'personal', so have pledged the funds we raise to a charity working in Cambodia, in the event that we possibly sell in the future.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise $200,000 to pay 'our sponsor' out.
  • If we don't reach our goal this time, funds will be held towards paying the old man out and we'll try again.
  • If we raise more than we need, surplus will be donated to a charity working in Cambodia.
  • In the event of Jasmine Valley being sold by us, we will donate the amount contributed, or, for every $1000 raised in this crowdfunding effort, we will donate 0.25% of the sale price to a charity working in Cambodia.  Which ever is a higher amount.  This means the same money gets used twice for good stuff.
  • We can offer funders discounts on your room prices if you're traveling to Cambodia.  It would be wonderful (and quite emotional) to meet you!  Perks may be claimed withing two years of the closing date of our campaign.

The Impact

We have worked very hard and have achieved incredible results.  Please visit our website to see just what we have achieved in such a short period of time at www.jasminevalley.com.  Pease also read about Jasmine at http://www.jasminevalley.com/jasmine.html and about Owen at http://www.jasminevalley.com/owen.html.  If you wish, you can also find more information about Owen at www.owenbeckhonours.com.

Your contributions will make a tremendous impact on us, our staff, and the ongoing contibution Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort makes to the community in Kep and Cambodia.  You will be protecting an ecologically sensible and socially responsible resort that's loved by thousands of travelers each year and very much enjoyed my Cambodian residents and their families.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, please pass the word to your friends using the Indiegogo share tools, facebook, twitter, email your friends.  We really are very desperate, so every bit of help is very much appreciated.
 
 
Thanks so much.
 
Owen and Jasmine.
story_txt:
The History, the Project and the Problem
Jasmine's childhood was as rough as they come, gowing up in a poor, rural Cambodian village.  She had no dad, she scavenged rubbish for a living as a four-year-old, she was chased out of roadside shack-restaurants for trying to scavenge food, pot-bellied with malnutrition.  She nursed her beloved mother to a death from AIDS, sometimes finding her in her own defecation and covered in ants.  She was sold off as an orphan to be used as a pre-pubescent sex toy.  It all went down hill from there.
Owen was born in Daru, an island off Papua New Guinea and raised in Perth, Australia.  He had a rural-urban middle-class upbringing, and has always been something of an artist-come-eccentric, affectionately referred to in one review as "a real life eco-Willy Wonka".  His projects have often involved community and social responsibility in one way or another, whether it be with Aboriginal Australians, victims of the devastating Boxing-Day-Tsunami in Aceh, or poor Cambodians. 
Owen and Jasmine married in 2008, and were working towards one day building an eco-resort that would not only be a wonderful place to live, but would also benefit poor Cambodians. They didn't have enough cash yet, and Owen had been offered a well-paid job if he had an English teaching certificate so went to Phuket to train for a couple of weeks.  While there he met an old man who was also there looking for a change of career.  Owen looked out for him, and they spent quite a bit of the ‘spare time’ together during the course. About a week in, the old guy asked Owen if he had any ideas for a project that might be good for some poor Cambodians, and he told him about the Jasmine Valley project, which he was working towards. The old fellow offered to finance it so it could happen more quickly – an offer Owen initially turned down because the risk of business in Cambodia is high, and it would be crazy to borrow for such a project. The old guy insisted that this wasn’t a ‘loan’ as such, but that Owen should reinvest everything back into the project for the first years, then only pay him back if he’s still alive when Jasmine Valley is making good money. This all seemed too good to be true, but the old guy assured Owen there were many rich Americans looking for philanthropic opportunities; people who didn’t want to “just will their money to the university”. He said he had already given his sons houses and they didn’t need any more money. He also said that he’d lost a million dollars in the Global Financial Crisis, and would prefer to risk losing money on a project that would be good for people in need. So, they agreed. Owen asked that they put things in writing, and the old man insisted it be a gentleman’s agreement, and that we just shake hands. With that, Owen shook his hand and promised he would do his best, but that was all he could promise. As things panned out, Owen received an inheritance and sold his house, all of which he committed to the project, so with the combined moneys and a great deal of very hard work Owen and Jasmine built an eco-resort that is currently still functioning as a social enterprise helping young, very undereducated, very poor Cambodians. It was very problematic, and once they had what they considered a serious complaint, Owen was professionally and ethically obliged to raise it with the old man. If he didn’t, Jasmine Valley (and Owen and Jasmine personally) would have likely gained a very unsavoury reputation, as Kep, and even Cambodia, is a very small community. It could well have destroyed them.They felt very conflicted because of their financial relationship with the old man and their duty to confront him, but Owen raised the complaint with him and he became very angry. He then proceeded to meet with Owen's colleagues and their families to tell them that Owen had stolen his money and intended to steal more. Nothing could be further from the truth, but it seems he had successfully convinced himself of things he needed to believe in order to begin making real trouble for Owen and Jasmine. 
And there was trouble. To cut a long story short, the old man has demanded that Owen and Jasmine return his money, plus 12% pa interest. Of course, they didn’t have the financial resources to do that, because it had all been used to create Jasmine Valley Eco-Resort.  They have made several offers in good faith to give him the money back over time, but he has refused all offers and has taken them to court in a country where ‘money talks’. He would be laughed out of court in America or Australia. He has asked the court to sell everything Jasmine and Owen own and give him the money. Incidentally, the old man recently made an offer outside the court. It would have been very difficult for them to service, but they accepted nevertheless in order to stop this ridiculous conflict. He then retracted his offer, for no apparent reason, as they walked into the court. It appears to be a game for him.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $200,000 to pay 'our sponsor' out.
If we don't reach our goal this time, funds will be held towards paying the old man out and we'll try again.
If we raise more than we need, surplus will be donated to a charity working in Cambodia.

In the event of Jasmine Valley being sold by us, we will donate the amount contributed, or, for every $1000 raised in this crowdfunding effort, we will donate 0.25% of the sale price to a charity working in Cambodia.  Which ever is a higher amount.   This means the same money gets used twice for good stuff.

story:
The campaign video above has closed-caption titles for people with a hearing impairment. You can turn titles on or off using the button on the YouTube control bar at the bottom of the video window.

Please remember to use the indiegogo share buttons above to share this campaign with your friends and colleagues!

Wow!! Look what I got!

What it's all about

Simple version - We're starting a radically different new fine-art publishing business - When customers subscribe for £5 a month or £50 a year, we send them a fine-art print of one of our artworks every month! We're running this project to raise the money to buy the equipment to get started.

wowlookwhatigot.com is two artists, Martin Herbert and Vivi-Mari Carpelan, from Britain and Finland respectively, who married in 2010 and currently live and work in Mid-Wales in the UK. We are two creative people who are being stifled by lack of opportunity and we intend to fix that.

It would be tempting at this point to say something like "It's increasingly difficult to make a living as an artist in the current economic climate", but actually that's not true. It doesn't go nearly far enough. It's actually pretty much impossible unless you're one of the elite few favored by the big galleries. The result is that we're scrabbling around to find enough money to buy food at the end of the month. I mean, yeah, you gotta suffer for your art, man, but enough's enough, OK?

No point sitting round wingeing about it - time to get up and do something. On the one hand we have artists desperate to sell some creative work (that would be us!) and on the other we have people who love art but can't afford to buy it (and maybe that's you!). Our idea is to bring the two together by creating a new kind of art market where each month, for a low price subscription (like a magazine), people get a new, thought provoking, unusual piece of artwork - the sort of thing, in fact, that makes you want to show your friends and say "Wow! Look what I got this month!" Our byline will be "Build an art collection for only £5 a month!".

The main object of this campaign is to raise the money to buy a production-quality large format printer to use in our project. The more we raise the more efficient our creative process is going to be. Your help could help give us the freedom to carry on creating art without constantly worrying about where the money to pay the next bill is coming from, so please contribute to the project, and we promise you'll get some fabulous art in return!

What we need from you (the crowd!)

Ideally we want to raise £5000 – that's around $8000. It will buy a high quality fast large-format digital giclée printer and other equipment and materials we need to produce the best possible fine-art prints to send to our subscribers. So we're turning to you to ask for contributions. Even if you don't want the art landing on your mat, the minimum contribution is only $1 (about 70p) 'cos every bit helps! Larger contributions mean you get more art - simple, huh?

What you get from us - perks that keep on giving!

First off, let's make it clear - by contributing to the project you are not signing up for a membership, a subscription, or any kind of repeat billing. For the basic contribution of $8 (£5)* we'll send you one sample fine-art print, then a second month's piece free. Then, and only then, we'll ask if you're sufficiently impressed to want to take out regular membership of wowlookwhatigot.com and get a new piece of art every month. Please take a look at the other 'perks' - for a campaign contribution of as little as $75* you could have more than a year's worth of art!
(Currency exchange: Note $1 is approximately 70p (UK) or 0.80€ ) **

To show you the kind of thing we'll be sending there are lots of links below to our website, blog, and a whole gallery of artwork. We're planning to start with a basic format of an A5 sized print of our own artwork, but we'll vary things with commissions from other artists, posters, trading cards, maybe even DVDs of video art! The possibilities are endless - that's what makes it such an exciting project for us and, we hope, for you. Please take a good look around - as the campaign goes on we'll be posting links to more work, our personal blogs and websites etc, so you can get to know us better.

I almost forgot to mention the best thing... for any contribution, even just $1 to show you like us, you get on the newsletter mailing list, which gives you invitations to exhibition private views, news of auctions of our original art, future membership offers, and details of other events - anything we can think of, in fact, that will make art more exciting!

Make a gift of art!

Our 'Hockney', 'Picasso', 'da Vinci' or 'Rafael' perks make fabulous gifts for a loved one. If you'd like to make a contribution and give your perk as a gift to someone else, please let us know by email (info@wowlookwhatigot.com) when you've completed checkout and we'll send you a gift card and get the address where we need to send the art.

What if it all goes pear-shaped, guv?

If we don't reach our goal then we may still have enough to do things on a smaller scale. A few hundred pounds will enable us to get a smaller second-hand giclée printer and allow us to get our art out of the door and on people's walls! The whole idea is to enable us to get art to people, and we'll do it to the best of our ability. In the event we just don't raise enough money to be useful then of course everyone gets their contributions back, but please understand we have to pay around 10% costs (indiegogo and PayPal commissions, for instance) so we may not be able to quite return 100%.

On the other hand, if we raise more than our target, we'll be able to buy bigger, better and faster printing equipment, more materials, etc. We may be able to contract out delivery to a bulk mailing compnay, freeing up more of our time for actually creating art, maybe even pay advance rent on a studio and production space - don't worry - the money will go into making a more sustainable future for us as artists.

So what else?

There's one more thing we would ask of you. Please SHARE! The only way we will raise the money we need for the project is if not hundreds, but thousands, nay - hundreds of thousands of people come here and read this. There are buttons just underneath the campaign video at the top of this page which you can use to share our campaign on social media or email it directly to someone. Please, don't only tell your friends, but beg them to tell their friends, and so on... If you contribute, or if you sign up for the newsletter on our website then you'll get regular updates during the campaign that you can forward to anyone you think may be interested. Remember - Donate & share!

Note: If you just can't contribute to the campaign right now, but you'd like to keep in touch with what's going on anyway, you can sign up for the newletter by clicking here.

* - please note there is a small extra cost for international shipping. Please add at checkout as requested in the perk details.

** - All currency conversions are approximate and for information only.

story:
Our Story 

Sierra Leoneï¿½s social fabric has been torn apart by decade-long civil war, with absolute decline of youth into fields of education and training, drastically leading to unemployment and social mayhem. Today, many young girls are out in the street fending for daily survival via prostitution, whereas young men are also found abusing drugs and armed robbery. 


Through the Sustainable Youth Livelihood and Empowerment Programof the Youth Partnership for Peace & Development, we help illiterate young women and girls uplift themselves from poverty via livelihood skills. Our project helps educate victims/survivors of domestic gender-based violence with the tools they need to build better futures and overcome poverty. Help us uplift the poverty of women in Sierra Leone, a major effort towards reducing economic vulnerability and instilling dignity for our mothers, our sisters.


Ramatu's Story (A single parent and victim of domestic and Gender-Based Violence)

Ramatu Bangura is a 19 years old young woman living in the Northern Province Town of Sierra Leone ï¿½ Makeni, with 3 children. She was on a hot afternoon Saturday beaten by her husband and was asked to quit the home together with her children. She is currently engaged in learning tailoring/dressmaking and textiles design to enable her take care of her three children and paying rents. Ramatu, like many of her types continues to face similar problem and requires your help.


The Project

Weï¿½re changing communities from within and creating a common language of hope for an already hopeless situation. Iï¿½m in; are you? Beneficiaries of this project are provided training at no cost.

Youth Partnership for Peace and Development want to continue to improve access to non-formal education through the provision of vocational skills training for vulnerable youth who are mainly war-affected victims, teenage mothers and former combatants. This will increase access to sustainable livelihoods, reduce youth unemployment, violence and promote self-reliance and sustainable peace in the country. It will benefit 40 illiterate, war-affected, drop-outs and ex-combatants youth within the age limits of 15 and 30 and will last for a year. Beneficiaries will be trained in dressmaking and textiles design inclusive gara-tye dye, entrepreneurship, basic measurement and calculation. Tutors will be employed for the project duration especially for the tailoring and textiles design.

Trainees will be certified and given sewing machines and other materials/equipment as a start-up kits that will assist them in setting up their own cooperatives. Regular and periodic monitoring will form part of this project.

javascript:nicTemp();

The Impact

The projectï¿½s goal is to address the acute poverty and unemployment faced by young women who are victims of sexual and gender-based violence by proving supports through practical and vocational skills training and start-up facilities to 40 beneficiaries a year that will enable them to be employed within a 12 months period.

We want to continue to offer an opportunity for each young woman in situations of extreme violence and poverty so they can in turn change their lives and give to others. To do that, I need your support for that I cannot do it alone. A little from each of us can do so much in the life of a young woman! 


What We Need & What You Get

We need $5,000. The amount you donate will directly do to the following budget lines:

  • Procurement of Wooden Stool for Trainees (10 additional) @ $20
  • Purchase of Sewing Machines (additional 10) @ $150 = $1500
  • Payment of Training Center Rent (yearly) @ $1500
  • Payment Stipends to 1 Training Center Staff (50% cost)  @150 = $1800  

  • See What You Get
  • For every donation you make, your contribution will be acknowledged with your name tag created to join our Goodwill Ambassadors
  • You will also be mentioned during the end of year graduation ceremony for beneficiaries.
  • Your name will also be inscribed on any amount of sewing machine your donation could go for.
  • Acknowledgment in our annual report
  • Be added to our website as a partner and contributor to change
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thinking of supporting the project in another form? Sure, you've got unlimited ways of helping to contribute to the change. Bet a part to this project by contributing in whatever way you can as your little assistance will help change lives for victims of domestic and gender-based violence in Sierra Leone.


You can forward this fundraising link to friends, families and others within your network.

  • Host a fundraising event in your community and we'll always be happy supporting you in an way possible.
  • You can even design a program involving talk show in schools, colleges and universities in your area and a volunteer will be happy joining you there.
  • You can donate equipment such as sewing machines, used computers and a whole lot of other relevant items that will help the project realize its vision.
  • Serve as one of our International Ambassadors.
YES!
YOU TOO CAN HELP US LET THE WORD OUT TO FRIENDS, FAMILY AND COLLEAGUES
story_txt:
Our Story 
Sierra Leoneï¿½s social fabric has been torn apart by decade-long civil war, with absolute decline of youth into fields of education and training, drastically leading to unemployment and social mayhem. Today, many young girls are out in the street fending for daily survival via prostitution, whereas young men are also found abusing drugs and armed robbery. 

Through the Sustainable Youth Livelihood and Empowerment Programof the Youth Partnership for Peace & Development, we help illiterate young women and girls uplift themselves from poverty via livelihood skills. Our project helps educate victims/survivors of domestic gender-based violence with the tools they need to build better futures and overcome poverty. Help us uplift the poverty of women in Sierra Leone, a major effort towards reducing economic vulnerability and instilling dignity for our mothers, our sisters.

Ramatu's Story (A single parent and victim of domestic and Gender-Based Violence)
Ramatu Bangura is a 19 years old young woman living in the Northern Province Town of Sierra Leone ï¿½ Makeni, with 3 children. She was on a hot afternoon Saturday beaten by her husband and was asked to quit the home together with her children. She is currently engaged in learning tailoring/dressmaking and textiles design to enable her take care of her three children and paying rents. Ramatu, like many of her types continues to face similar problem and requires your help.

The Project
Weï¿½re changing communities from within and creating a common language of hope for an already hopeless situation. Iï¿½m in; are you? Beneficiaries of this project are provided training at no cost.


Youth Partnership for Peace and Development want to continue to improve access to non-formal education through the provision of vocational skills training for vulnerable youth who are mainly war-affected victims, teenage mothers and former combatants. This will increase access to sustainable livelihoods, reduce youth unemployment, violence and promote self-reliance and sustainable peace in the country. It will benefit 40 illiterate, war-affected, drop-outs and ex-combatants youth within the age limits of 15 and 30 and will last for a year. Beneficiaries will be trained in dressmaking and textiles design inclusive gara-tye dye, entrepreneurship, basic measurement and calculation. Tutors will be employed for the project duration especially for the tailoring and textiles design.
Trainees will be certified and given sewing machines and other materials/equipment as a start-up kits that will assist them in setting up their own cooperatives. Regular and periodic monitoring will form part of this project.
javascript:nicTemp();
The Impact
The projectï¿½s goal is to address the acute poverty and unemployment faced by young women who are victims of sexual and gender-based violence by proving supports through practical and vocational skills training and start-up facilities to 40 beneficiaries a year that will enable them to be employed within a 12 months period.
We want to continue to offer an opportunity for each young woman in situations of extreme violence and poverty so they can in turn change their lives and give to others. To do that, I need your support for that I cannot do it alone. A little from each of us can do so much in the life of a young woman! 

What We Need & What You Get
We need $5,000. The amount you donate will directly do to the following budget lines:

Procurement of Wooden Stool for Trainees (10 additional) @ $20
Purchase of Sewing Machines (additional 10) @ $150 = $1500
Payment of Training Center Rent (yearly) @ $1500 
Payment Stipends to 1 Training Center Staff (50% cost)  @150 = $1800  



See What You Get
For every donation you make, your contribution will be acknowledged with your name tag created to join our Goodwill Ambassadors
You will also be mentioned during the end of year graduation ceremony for beneficiaries.
Your name will also be inscribed on any amount of sewing machine your donation could go for.
Acknowledgment in our annual report
Be added to our website as a partner and contributor to change

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Thinking of supporting the project in another form? Sure, you've got unlimited ways of helping to contribute to the change. Bet a part to this project by contributing in whatever way you can as your little assistance will help change lives for victims of domestic and gender-based violence in Sierra Leone.

You can forward this fundraising link to friends, families and others within your network.

Host a fundraising event in your community and we'll always be happy supporting you in an way possible.
You can even design a program involving talk show in schools, colleges and universities in your area and a volunteer will be happy joining you there.
You can donate equipment such as sewing machines, used computers and a whole lot of other relevant items that will help the project realize its vision.
Serve as one of our International Ambassadors.


YES!
YOU TOO CAN HELP US LET THE WORD OUT TO FRIENDS, FAMILY AND COLLEAGUES

story:
For those of you who do not know, and as a reminder to those who do, Josh hurt his knee during our first week of spring kickball.  It was later discovered that he has a full ACL tear, as well as a torn Miniscus which will require surgery.  He will be out of work for a few months as a result.  On top of that, Josh's lovely wife Meagan just gave birth to their first child.

The purpose of this fund is to raise some money to help Josh and Meagan with whatever they may need, such as medical bills or anything else that may pop up.  I ask you all to help out a fellow kickballer by donating or at least spreading the word to help Josh and Meagan.  Let's show our support!  All money donated will be given to Josh and Meagan at the end of May. Thank you all!

story:
Thank you for getting Sunny Days Screenprinting started!

The Big Green T-Shirt Printing Expriment

(TL;DR if you pledge more I'll print with green materials)

I'd like to print on Recycled scrap cotton, recycled plastic bottle, hemp and other green t-shirts using discharge water-based ink and every possible green practice that I can figure out.

Unfortunately, going green is expensive. Operating costs are easily twice that of more normal industry practices.

Most of the t-shirts you see and own were printed on on Fruit of the Loom, Sanmar, Gilden, and Port and Co shirts with plasticol ink.  The people who print those shirts,  98% of all screenprinters, feel that's the only way to keep the price down low enough to be competitive.

However I would to like explore the green niche in the market: I feel like there are enough t-shirt buyers out there who are willing to spend extra for green practices that Sunny Days could be successful as a green screenprinter.

But maybe not.  I'd like to try this experiment:

Normal Tier, Green Tier

If Sunny Days reaches it's $1200 goal or less (That's 48 shirts at $25 per shirt) then I'll print the shirts with normal industry practices.

If Sunny Days reaches $2000 (with around 50% or more pledgers donating more then $25 per shirt) I'll go green and print on recycled or hemp shirts with discharge ink.

The big difference is that I already own the normal ink; it came with the press.  But I'll have to buy the discharge ink and the more expensive shirts.

Why not just go all green and print fewer shirts?  Because using the shirts as an advertising tool is absolutely necessary to gain a client base, the bigger the better. Printing a lot of shirts is essential to make the business work out.

Softer ink

Plasticol ink is the usual ink for screenprinting; it has a slightly rubbery feel, or if layered up for many colors, a thick rubbery feel that screenprinters call "bulletproof". Water based discharge ink is much, much softer.  So pledge more and get softer shirts.

So Pledge!

And thank you so much for doing it.  The money goes to bootstrapping Sunny Days Screenprinting into existence as my hobby business and hopefully, someday, as my real business.  Specifically the money will go into printing as many of Alameda Sun shirts as I can:  I'll give those shirts to great potential clients in order to build a client base here in Alameda.

story:
What we're building

We're building a mobile and web product that can help companies and small teams determine their employees' level of happiness and be proactive in motivating them by offering a simple yet effective suite of mobile and web tools that are fun and easy to use.

Our product will be mostly aimed towards:

  • Small and medium business.
  • Specific departments in big companies.
  • NGOs and universities.

Yoy can visit our blog or subscribe to get invited when we launch the limited beta. We'll be announcing some future features aswell in January.

What We Need & What You Get

This isn't very often said: we don't need money that much. We have a great team, but we'd really be happy to have your support so we can launch the product faster. You can help us out financially or by recomending our website so we have a big enough audience to help us launch and get feedback that will set the long term course for our product.

We're more than happy to provide lifetime free access to the product to anyone who backs us up.

Our plan

We aim to launch an MVP as a limited Beta in January 2013 and after that we'll rush to get the public product available as soon as possible (between 1 and 3 months depending on user feedback).

Our goal is to have a web product that can be used as well on all mobile platforms: Windows, Android and iOS by the end of 2013.

The product will always have a free version since many of the features will be aimed to NGOs and even education. 

Our team

When it comes to startups we all know that the team is vital to success. We have a great blend of creatives (a designer and a seasoned digital marketing veteran) and developers (we're backed by ThinSlices, a mobile product development company).

story:
With our decades of expertise and experience, we aim to create a solar powered car that resembles an average consumer vehicle without compromising our previous performance. We’ve proven time and again that our cars can drive fast; now we have to show we can do it while making it familiar, attractive, and most importantly, practical.






Still don’t think this car can handle the road? We’ll take you up on your challenge! The University of Waterloo Midnight Sun is planning a tour of North America. Details have not been finalized, but we will determine our route from the location of our backers. Support us if want Midnight Sun to come visit!




We really want to make the trip happen. However, your help is needed to make it a reality. The cost of building the car is significant, and the journey we planned needs money as well. To give you an idea of what we’re up against:


We understand how important your help is in transforming our dream into a reality. To show our appreciation, we offer supporters a variety of neat bonuses.

















*Please note that international shipping fees may cost extra.


The Midnight Sun team believes in a greener tomorrow, in which renewable resources will provide the daily energy needs of the world. MS XI will be no different. Our cars are important in sharing the vision with others. They apply and demonstrate leading breakthroughs in solar energy, a significant avenue of practical renewable energy. Our educational and community outreach programs can only succeed if we show firsthand how far solar technology has come along. The Midnight Sun race cars are a physical embodiment of our dream and prove to others that it can become a reality.



The Midnight Sun also wants to change the insular nature of solar car projects with MS XI. While solar competitions are impressive for people already invested in this form of energy, it does little to persuade the skeptical or indifferent. We want to change the culture of solar cars to be less about maximizing performance and more about making them practical for everyday use. Our hope is that MS XI succeeds, promoting forward-thinking designs that matter to the average person.

story:
GalGael 2014: be part of carving out the next chapter!

On the face of it, GalGael work with people whose lives have been battered by homelessness, addiction and depression. Walk through the door of our workshop and you’ll find purposeful creativity and something beyond a strong sense of community. At our workbenches, skills and self-belief are built. Everywhere hands-on work creates hope and worth. Our methods are simple and effective but time and again we see folk fall. The pressure of life beyond the walls of the safe harbour we’ve created is too great. 

That’s why we understand our work as being more than with individuals. The issues they may arrive with - are the product of a society that’s off course – more than an indication they’ve somehow failed. Too many apparent solutions deal only with symptoms. Too many have been left high and dry by post-industrial realities of individualism and transaction. Roots are being lost and values blurred. 

At GalGael, we have created a cultural anchor point around which people are re-kindling skills, community and new narratives for the future. It’s brought us to the conclusion that it is not only people who need retraining but no less than society itself that needs re-worked. This thinking is at the cutting edge of our work. It’s a tall task and we don’t plan on doing it alone. We need the backing of like-minded individuals like you. With your help - we’re forging ahead with some bold ideas.

Just as our story wouldn’t be possible without the thousands of folk who’ve helped write it so far, we need support from people like you to help us write the next chapter. Your contribution will help GalGael to grow its unique form of social innovation around positive learning experiences anchored in practical activities that offer connection and meaning.

These new approaches are already starting to deliver results and rewrite life stories and in the past 6 months; 

  • 5 people have gone into employment; 
  • 3 in traditional crafts; 
  • 11 people have become volunteers; 
  • 5 have enrolled in further education;
  • and 45 who have taken part in our Journey On programme.

Your contributions will help us carve out the next chapter of GalGael’s work. Part of that is creating a workplace that challenges, inspires and creates the conditions for the individuals we work with to carve out their next chapter, which sometimes is leaving behind life stories that have been marked by isolation, and the kind of bankruptcy of hope that lead to addiction. As one of our people put it; “This is the first place has felt safe, GalGael. My head never stops but this helps make it more bearable.” 

For many of our people experiencing progressively harsh benefits cuts, we are the difference between hope and hardship. People who have been made to feel they have no part to play in society - their confidence stripped by countless structures. In that sense, we don’t see ourselves as a charity, but more a community of creative people, who come together to co-operatively meet some of our needs; our shared need for acceptance, to learn and contribute our creativity. Come down and see for yourself.

As our founder Colin Macleod said; “It’s not enough to have the great dream. We’re interested in people who want to wrestle it into reality and that means getting your sleeves rolled up and dealing with the rough as well as the smooth...” We’ve been rolling our sleeves up for the last 17 years. There have been some rough times but it’s been worth it and all that hard graft is paying off. You can read more on our website about our work that continues to push boundaries and is increasingly gaining recognition. 

Our work spans the best part of two decades and reads a bit like a story. It’s woven with the human stories of those who’ve worked with us over that time - adding depth and life that make that story what it is. Some of our work is about re-writing old, limiting stories; both personal and societal. Dr. Sandra Carlisle of the Afternow Project explains it like this; 

“Where it differs from virtually all other such organisations – making it probably unique – is in providing a different kind of ‘story’ by which to live and with which to think, and thus a different kind of purpose and meaning in life. This strength should not be underestimated, even if it might not be readily understood by outsiders to the project. The meanings and values that GalGael participants bring to their work differ sharply from those found in mainstream society, where the dominant social and cultural values appear to be economism, individualism, consumerism and materialism.”

GalGael offers day-in day-out a lived example of a different way for being in the world. It's not rocket science. Much of it is common sense. Our innovative model of work supports self-reliance among our participants, many of who are creating their own work because neither jobs nor benefits are readily available. The beauty of this model lies in that it does so at the same time as generating self-reliance for GalGael as a whole. But we still need wider support from people like you to ensure the continuation of our work. Your contribution will help make that happen. And if a contribution's not something you can offer right now, you can contribute by helping us get this campaign out there by sending it on to friends and family.

Short Summary

My name is Samantha Ridley.  After tours in both Iraq and Afghanistan my husband started showing signs of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  He tried to get help on his own but was unsuccessful.  He was then sent to treatment for alcoholism,   The treatment facility he was sent to was full of addicts from a different walk of life. Many of whom lived in half-way houses and were struggling to maintain the most basic necessities of life.  My husband, being a successful military officer was often asked in his group sessions,  "why are you even here?"  None of them were veterans and they just did not understand.  This is when we came up with the idea for the Circle of Veterans.  We want to create a place where our veterans and their families can commune and heal together.  Our counselors are passionate about what they do, and they understand the problem.
Without more programs like this, America could not see the epidemic among military families such as the suicide rate--22 servicemen per day.

What We Need & What You Get

Our programs include mental health professionals, healthy living instructors, urban gardening classes among other things.  We use animals in treatment such as horse therapy and service dogs for our families.

My husband and I have made it to this point on our own financially, but will be needing help with funding.  Unfortunately, most grants and loans require you to be in business already before they supply the funds.  We have found the farm home that is perfect for The Circle Veterans, and we are in the process of purchasing it.

Where we need your help:  

Therapies - Not all of our veterans and their families will have insurance or be compatible with the insurance our doctors accept.  They are passionate about what they do, but they can't work for free.

Animals - The cost of veterinarian care, food, fencing, etc. to care for the horses and service dogs can cost up to several thousand dollars.

Food - Our goal is to eventually grow our own food in our aquaponic gardens to be prepared daily in our kitchen.  However, initially we will cater the food at the cost of about $60 per day for a family of 4.  We intend to treat 2 families per week.

Farm hands and construction - The farm will be just as much therapy for us as it is for our veterans, but we have spent nearly 20 years as a military family and know nothing about raising farm animals... for now.  We will also need to modify the home to make it wheelchair accessible. 

The Impact

With the recent controversy at the Veterans Administration, it seems that their systems are just overwhelmed.  In addition to that, the VA only treats the veteran, leaving the family members to get help on their own.  Using our model, the entire family gets treated and we give them the resources to get further help in their own communities.  Our program can help about 70 families per year, but we hope our model will spread to countless organizations and facilities in order to help many more.

Risks & Challenges

Starting an organization like this is very complicated and we have dedicated a lot of our time and personal finances to the project.  We believe in our goals and need your help to reach them.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to support us financially and are local to the Dade City or Tampa area, we always welcome volunteers to help with the farming activities, construction projects, and art therapy for the children.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word about our noble cause.

Thank you very much for you time and consideration.

story:
Our Story


This April, a team of six canoeists will be setting out to make history by paddling across Canada in less then 170 days.  Among the six are 4 women who will be the first women ever recorded to have completed the journey in one season.  Our goal is to raise awareness for the Nature Conservancy of Canada and the Canadian Heritage River Systems.


We are paddlers.  We paddle flat water and moving water, in big boats and little boats and especially fast boats.  We have all spent the majority of our lives on the water.  We're keenly aware of the importance inland water transportation, by canoe, played in interconnecting the many different cultures and landscapes to forms the bonds that institute Canada.  Brought about by a passion for paddling and continual curiosity, the 2011 Canadan canoe Odyssey will remind audiences about the critical relevance of waterways to our culture, way of life and environment.


The Route


The odyssey begins April 2011 in Vancouver, BC. After more than 7000 kilometers of self propelled paddling and portaging—seven provinces; nearly 200 treacherous days—we will reach our destination, the shore of the Atlantic Ocean at St. John, NB.

Our route will take us through BC by a variety of rivers, lakes, reservoirs, paths and passes, including seven portages totaling more than 300 km. On major portages including the Kettle Valley Railway from Hope, B.C. to Summerland B.C. and the Blaeberry Road towards Howse Pass, we will use bicycles to pull the canoes with custom designed carts. After crossing the continental divide through Howse Pass, we will launch in the headwaters of the North Saskatchewan River and follow its course through Alberta and Saskatchewan on to Cedar Lake and Lake Winnipeg. From Lake Winnipeg we will paddle against the Winnipeg and Rainy Rivers and through northwestern Ontario’s Boundary Waters to Lake Superior. Lakes Superior and Huron will take us eastward until the outlet of the French River. Paddling up the French River, we will cross over into the Ottawa River drainage basin and paddle downstream to the St. Lawrence. At Rivière-du-Loup, we will travel south portaging and paddling on the Riviere Vert and St. Francis River to the St. John River and paddle downstream to the Bay of Fundy.


The Impact


During the trip we intend to document our travels visually, by capturing video footage and photographs, and individually, by recording our anecdotal impressions of the adventure. Detailed records of our progress will be kept including time, portages, rate of travel, and the spectacular sights and striking vistas we’ll encounter enroute. When possible we will record the perspectives of those we meet along the river. Our website will also be updated throughout the journey. The culmination of our documentation will be a film to be submitted to the Banff Mountain Film Festival and the Reel Paddling Film Festival.


What We Need & What You Get

As you can imagine, this trip has significant start up cost, between the canoes and gear, to the maps and safety equipment to the food and shipping costs of delivering everything to the designated pick-up spots throughout the route, we our estimating our costs to be around $7000 per person. We have seeked out a number of sponsorships from companies and have received discounted gear, but still need help to make this thing possible!


Other Ways You Can Help

All donations are greatly appreciated, please send this along to your friends and family, the more people it reaches the better!  Remember every dollar counts in making this trip possible.
story_txt:
Our Story

This April, a team of six canoeists will be setting out to make history by paddling across Canada in less then 170 days.  Among the six are 4 women who will be the first women ever recorded to have completed the journey in one season.  Our goal is to raise awareness for the Nature Conservancy of Canada and the Canadian Heritage River Systems.

We are paddlers.  We paddle flat water and moving water, in big boats and little boats and especially fast boats.  We have all spent the majority of our lives on the water.  We're keenly aware of the importance inland water transportation, by canoe, played in interconnecting the many different cultures and landscapes to forms the bonds that institute Canada.  Brought about by a passion for paddling and continual curiosity, the 2011 Canadan canoe Odyssey will remind audiences about the critical relevance of waterways to our culture, way of life and environment.

The Route

The odyssey begins April 2011 in Vancouver, BC.  After more than 7000
 kilometers of self propelled paddling and portaging—seven provinces; 
nearly 200 treacherous days—we will reach our destination, the shore of 
the Atlantic Ocean at St. John, NB. 
Our route will take us 
through BC by a variety of rivers, lakes, reservoirs, paths and passes, 
including seven portages totaling more than 300 km.  On major portages 
including the Kettle Valley Railway from Hope, B.C. to Summerland B.C. 
and the Blaeberry Road towards Howse Pass, we will use bicycles to pull 
the canoes with custom designed carts.  After crossing the continental 
divide through Howse Pass, we will launch in the headwaters of the North
 Saskatchewan River and follow its course through Alberta and 
Saskatchewan on to Cedar Lake and Lake Winnipeg.  From Lake Winnipeg we 
will paddle against the Winnipeg and Rainy Rivers and through 
northwestern Ontario’s Boundary Waters to Lake Superior.  Lakes Superior
 and Huron will take us eastward until the outlet of the French River.  
Paddling up the French River, we will cross over into the Ottawa River 
drainage basin and paddle downstream to the St. Lawrence.   At 
Rivière-du-Loup, we will travel south portaging and paddling on the 
Riviere Vert and St. Francis River to the St. John River and paddle 
downstream to the Bay of Fundy.   

The Impact

During the trip we intend to document our travels visually, by capturing
 video footage and photographs, and individually, by recording our 
anecdotal impressions of the adventure.  Detailed records of our 
progress will be kept including time, portages, rate of travel, and the 
spectacular sights and striking vistas we’ll encounter enroute.  When 
possible we will record the perspectives of those we meet along the 
river. Our website will also be updated throughout the journey.   The 
culmination of our documentation will be a film to be submitted to the 
Banff Mountain Film Festival and the Reel Paddling Film Festival. 


What We Need & What You Get
As you can imagine, this trip has significant start up cost, between the canoes and gear, to the maps and safety equipment to the food and shipping costs of delivering everything to the designated pick-up spots throughout the route, we our estimating our costs to be around $7000 per person. We have seeked out a number of sponsorships from companies and have received discounted gear, but still need help to make this thing possible!


Other Ways You Can Help
All donations are greatly appreciated, please send this along to your friends and family, the more people it reaches the better!  Remember every dollar counts in making this trip possible.

story:
Our Story

Michael came out when he was in high school. He grew up with the people around him telling him what gay was. Because of that he had a warped perception of what it meant to be gay. The first image is what he thought it meant if you were gay. The second images is what being gay means to him now.

“I really thought that being gay just in itself would be hard. God hates you, according to some. Society fears you – because you don’t fit into their expectations. You get called names like “Faggot! Queer! Freak!” Your family can’t even look at you because they’re ashamed…or annoyed…or both. It’s the one taboo subject; that white elephant in the room, which never gets discussed. That’s a lot of pressure; yet, it’s so much more than that. It is the idea that you always have to look over your shoulder; that there is this unconscious, unspoken fear to be on the defensive; it’s about learning who you can trust – and it’s about the true disappointment when you discover that the ones you’re supposed to rely on abandon their responsibilities.

The funny thing was, I didn’t understand being gay myself so it was really difficult to help others understand it as well. As it was, I didn’t have any answers for anyone, not even myself. It took me several years to even know what to call it. Growing up, hitting puberty, understanding the changes in my body. I just knew I was different than anyone else. The other boys I hung out with were looking at girls….but I was looking at the other boys.

I wanted to feel accepted…feel alive!

I spent every day hating myself, finding ways to escape who I was. I couldn’t even look at myself in the mirror because there was this “other” person staring back at me. I considered suicide every day because I thought it would be easier to do that than admit who I was. I couldn’t turn my back on all of that anymore. I had to come out. I wanted respect from other people more than anything. I didn’t think that was asking too much. Besides, it’s not like I threw it in anyone’s face. So why did I have to edit my life for those who were…who still are uncomfortable with it? I was really one person with two identities: me, the person and me, the gay man. What I wanted were people to be able to distinguish the difference between the two and see that I was just like everyone else. I didn’t ask for this. Although the way people acted you would’ve thought my being gay was a personal attack against them. That doesn’t even make sense – but it’s true. It’s like this: I love men! – That’s the simple truth – the way they look, the way they smell…even the way they feel. I wish I knew the words to describe these feelings. I have such ansias; such nervous tension, almost like the anxiety a young child feels the night before Christmas: the rush of excitement and innocent pleasure in the anticipation of the first ray of sun that signals the new day.

You know the feeling you get in your stomach when you drop suddenly? That happens when I see a masculine face with beautiful brown eyes look at me, or when their hand reaches for my cheek to caress it; or my heart stops right before they step in for the first kiss; or how my palms sweat profusely and I switch from one foot to the other when I am brave enough to ask an attractive man out on a date. How can I capture the essence of both the sorrow and joy of that love I feel to someone who only sees me with an abhorrent disgust in their heart? Hatred caused from their own deceitful fear – which have this self-obligated obsession to reprimand me with their own morals…when they themselves suffer just as I do. You can’t. It’s hypocrisy. Yet as a gay man I was relegated to an object that needed to be destroyed.

And I understand that less than I understand being gay.”

-Michael Coulombe



MyAcceptance.org is an ongoing photo essay project that documents members of the Lesbian, Gay, Bi, and Transgender community by creating two photos.  The first one represents how they felt growing up and the second shows how they feel now.  Each set of photos is accompanied by a deeply personal story written by the subject as they discuss their journey towards hope and self-acceptance.  We hope to travel across the United States so that we can photograph and document everyone's story who wants to be involved.


The Impact

We want to document the stories of every member of the LGBT community that wants to be involved so that others who are struggling with their own self acceptance have a place to turn to for hope and inspiration.  To see that they are not alone and there are people out there who have gone through the same thing and have made it though those rough times.


What We Need & What You Get

The $15,000 that I'm asking for is so that I can travel across the country stopping in the major cities so that those in the area can be apart of the project. The money is used to the create the photo shoots, it pays for studio rentals, lighting equipment, supplies to create the set, and the travel costs like gas and lodging for the journey.  If the goal isn't reached then I plan on using that money that has been donated so that I can go to a few major cities like New York and San Francisco so that people in those areas can have their lives documented.   


Other Ways You Can Help

Go to our website: www.myacceptance.org and share your story, tell your friends, send emails.  If you believe in this project then please help!

story:
Why We're Going On A Mission Trip

For a couple of years now Stephanie and I have been looking for an opportunity to go on a mission trip through our church and over the past couple of months this opportunity for the Congo has gone from an idea to a reality. We have wanted to go on a mission trip because we feel like God has blessed us both with awesome skills, resources and other things that we feel could be used to help others in need around the world. It's easy to get all comfy here in the United States and not worry about other people, God has pushing us to do something radical so we thought that traveling to the Congo would do the trick.

More specifically, Ryan will be helping them with their technology needs and Stephanie will be teaching English and working in their orphanages. At least that's the plan right now. 


Why We're Going To The Congo

If you take a couple of minutes to read about the people of the Congo it won't take you long to realize how they've been taken advantage of and have suffered for literally hundreds of years. This is why even though the country is rich of valuable resources it's still the second poorest country in the entire world. Yeah, it's pretty wild. 

Since the early 1900's Christian missionaries started to take notice and began sending people over there to help. This has not only resulted in a major growth of Christianity in the Congo, but it has also helped the people of the Congo build a higher standard of living. Obviously they still have a long way to go before they have a sustainable, safe and healthy way of life, but through this help from mission-based organizations such as The Paul Carlson Partnership and churches like ours it can only get better. 

In fact, the missionaries and local church leaders have done such an awesome job building up the area of the Congo where we'll be traveling, the Congolese government has given them full authority to manage most of the foundational services like hospitals, schools and orphanages. Our plan is to help them out any way that we can with what they've already accomplished so far.  


Why We Need Your Help

First and foremost we need your prayers while we're over there in the Congo. As long as we have a group of people praying for our safety, success and motivation everything else will fall into place. So, please pray for us and pray often as we'll definitely need all that we can get. 

Secondly, it's not cheap to fly all the way across the world, so any donations that you can give will help us with the expenses that our church has to pay to make this mission trip happen. Just to give you an idea of how much it costs, we just booked our 2 tickets to the Congo and together it cost right around $4,000 (which is what we're trying to raise online). There are other costs involved, too but the plane tickets are definitely the biggest chunk of change we need to help cover. 


Want More Info? 

If you want some more information about our trip and how you can help out, check out this section that we created on our blog: HupandSteph.com/congo. 

Thanks for all of your help and if you have any questions for us, please feel free to email us at Hup [at] hupandsteph.com.
