story:
In America we have a problem ,  the problem is we have too much food. .  However for about 1/6 Americans,  this is not the land of opportunity,  it is the land of selfless greed. 
The real story  ...  I lost my job ,  had a small brother to help with bills,  and a single parent,  who made barely over 10 dollars an hour.  Trying to push something through the local bureaucracy,  to even get us the most minimal food assistance was a nightmare,  I would not want my worst enemy to live through.   Eventually we bottomed out and on top of being bankrupt,  we also lost our home,  and had no medical.   I vowed if I ever could do something about this I would,  and I would in a loud way.   
   

Many people believe that the problems associated with hunger are confined to small pockets of society, certain areas of the country, or certain neighborhoods, but the reality is much different.

Right now, millions of Americans are struggling with hunger.  These are often hard-working adults, children and seniors who simply cannot make ends meet and are forced to go without food for several meals, or even days.

The problem is 2 fold,   first is that we waste more food than most countrys produce,  We also export,  ahead of feeding our own more food that is throw away,  because foreign governments tell their people our food is poisoned,  through genetic modification. 
  Secondly,  the people who attempt to help you in the government,  frankly just don't care.  They are out to do as little work as possible,  to collect a paycheck.  Remember they are not working in the real world. .  They are not under pressure to produce anything , generate money,  or work at any pace or any harder than they want too.   A lesson I learned the hard way when I tried to get my 9 year old brother food assistance,  and I was left choosing between lunch,  or Asthma Medicine.   

From that day forward I vowed never to let this happen again,  if I could.  I am starting small ,  and getting the ball rolling.  We cannot afford to have this sort of problem anymore.    I have joined Feeding America,  as part of a college program,  to simply see how much 1 girl can make a difference with 1 campaign.   If everyone simply works together,  we can achieve amazing results.      And in the words of scripture
"Just as steel sharpens steel,  man sharpens man"   we are the only ones who can make each other better people

Kendall

story:
Our Story

In early 2013, we formed Exposure in downtown Sioux Falls with the purpose to provide gallery and studio space to artists of any discipline. In August, after experiencing issues with our building we decided to vacate our home. While Exposure was in operation, we welcomed in hundreds of visitors every First Friday to check out some wonderful local art and share refreshments with friends. Since then we've been searching for the perfect location to reopen Exposure and now we've finally found it!

Our new proposed space is nestled on the corner of 6th st. and Phillips Avenue. It's great location and large space provides the perfect venue for our artistic community. We'll be hosting monthly art parties on the first Friday of every month, having artists talks and critiques, and most importantly we'll have seven studio spaces for artists to create work in.

What We Need

In order to get Exposure back up and running we need help from you! Here's what we need to make the space great.

  • New lighting in the gallery spaces (we need to install track lighting in order to properly light all the awesome artwork we plan on displaying)
  • A couple of new walls (we're tearing down a few walls and putting up new ones to create more space for our main gallery space)
  • Paint for the walls and ceiling
  • General fund for operational needs

Why Should I donate?

The Sioux Falls arts scene is in an important stage right now. There is a growing population of young artists in Sioux Falls, but those artists aren't going to stick around if they don't have a place to show and sell their work. Exposure will provide an outlet for artists to work, create and exhibit their art. We aim not only to build up and support our art community, but our downtown community as well. 

Other Ways You Can Help!

We know not everyone can help contribute financially to our cause, but there are other great ways you can help. Here are just a few: 

  • Spread the word. Share this page and our upcoming shows on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or whatever social media you crazy kids are using these days;
  • Volunteer with clean up and construction. Once we move into our new space we'll need workers to help us make Exposure shiny and new again.
  • Attend our openings. Nothing makes us happier than seeing a lot of people at our art openings! Honestly, introducing people to new art and artists is what makes all the hard work worth it.

Final Word

Thank you so much for checking out our page and supporting us. Whether you donate $25 or $2000, we are overwhelmed with your commitment to art in Sioux Falls. If you're on the fence, I urge you to check out the side bar and take a look at all of our AMAZING perks for donating. We've got t-shirts, original artwork, limited edition prints and lots of other cool items. We couldn't be more excited to get rolling again and to bring some more art to downtown Sioux Falls. We'll see you in the Spring!

story:
CHECK OUT OUR NEW PERK WITH THIS AWESOME GRAPHIC!


Our Story

Leaving the house with diapered kiddos can be a daunting task.  The Sweet Cheeks Diaper Clutch helps parents feel put together, prepared, and organized while creating more "I've Got This" moments while away from home.

There is not another product on the market that functions like the Sweet Cheeks Diaper Clutch!
Here are the features that make the Diaper Clutch convenient:

1.  The baby wipes are always accessible, even when the clutch is closed!  No more scrambling for misplaced baby wipes amidst a mess, which provides parents with confidence and control over unexpected situations.

2.  Parents can always keep a good, safe hand on baby throughout the duration of diaper duty as the Diaper Clutch opens and closes with one hand, and unfolds to a large diaper pad with attached storage.

Other items don't offer the features available with the Sweet Cheeks Diaper Clutch.  You either have quick access to wipes and fumble around through pockets to lay out a pad and diaper essentials while holding your baby, OR the item is all-in-one and the wipes are tucked inside, so the entire pad must open to gain access to the wipes.  Rather annoying...and gross if you have to do this at a restaurant dinner table!

Sweet Cheeks is a mother-daughter team that is dedicated to creating multi-functional baby gear to help parents stay organized and in control of chaotic situations.

Fathers that once feared taking their baby to a public restroom because it felt overwhelming, now stride with confidence.  Mothers that once scrambled to grab baby wipes to clean a messy sneeze or food filled fingers, now clean it up with ease.

We will be launching our Wet Bag soon that fits perfectly in the Diaper Clutch to hold clothes that got soiled from a leaky diaper.

Give Together

We believe in raising balanced, well-rounded children, which is why we have partnered with Give Together.  A non-profit that offers volunteer opportunities for families with children as young as two years old.  Through volunteer opportunities children can develop compassion, learn the importance of gratitude and how they can make a difference.  Give Together is a movement that shapes the next generation of philanthropic leaders.  Sweet Cheeks makes a donation to Give Together for every purchase made on www.GoSweetCheeks.com.

What We Need

We are proud to have our products made in the USA and are looking to raise $5,000 to be able to purchase material in bulk, design product packaging and purchase the packaging to get our Diaper Clutch into retailers.  Purchasing in bulk allows us to have inventory in the patterns we want.  Since we are buying in small quantities as we go, we are limited to the patterns that are available and miss out on some of the fabulous patterns we know our customers will love!  
What You Get
We will highlight your name on the custom Campaign Thank You page on our website, an opportunity to donate to Give Together, and receive our Diaper Clutch or the Diaper Clutch and Wet Bag Combo through purchasing our Perks.  We appreciate your generosity and support of our campaign.  
Please allow 3-4 weeks for perk items to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us spread the word by using the Indiegogo Share Tool.  
  • Stay in touch and learn about our progress by signing up for our newsletters!  Click Here!

story:
Hello Everyone, My name is Kristina Kennedy, I am opening this fundraisier to help out my mother in law, Vicki Kennedy. Please do all you can to spread the word and help me get as much help as I can for her in this tragic time.

On Saturday, July 26th 2014, Tragedy struck the Kennedy family. Kip Kennedy, 61, Loving father of 4, grandfather, uncle, brother, husband, left this world very unexpectedly....He leaves behind  4 children, 7 grandchildren brothers and sister, and the love of his life for 38 years, Vicki.

This is a very sad but stressful time for there family, and unfortunatly, finanicially devastating. 

I am hoping to collect as much as I can for Vicki to help with bills, food, and everyday living expenses.  Please spread the word to help out in this devastaing time.

Thank you

Kristina Kennedy

story:
Since 2009, West Marin Advocacy (WMA) has assisted survivors of family violence and human trafficking. As a survivor of domestic violence and sexual exploitation, I was motivated to assist others in my community to live healthy and happy lives after experiencing trauma.

Here is a snapshot of how your contribution will help survivors:

1) Assistance accessing emergency shelter, medical care and advocacy to navigate the criminal justice system.

2) Advocacy obtaining restraining orders against abusers, including document preparation, transportation from shelter to court, and communication with offenders' probation/parole officers to ensure compliance.

3) Creation and printing of training materials, coordination of guest speakers and planning outreach and education projects with local nonprofit organizations, law enforcement agencies, schools and churches .

Benefits of donating:

You have the ability to help save lives in our community! And, your contribution will be fully tax deductible, thanks to the fiscal sponsorship of MarinLink, a 501 (c)(3) organization.

story:
The William Kellibrew Foundation (WKF) is excited to host its second “Ball For Peace” Basketball Tournament & Showcase in collaboration with the Men of Code program and Friendship Collegiate Academy Football in Washington, D.C. This community event is an afternoon of fun dedicated to the awareness and prevention of gun violence, domestic violence, and sexual assault. This event brings together youth, educators, athletes, organizations, and community leaders.  All funds raised will support the event and WKF’s ongoing programmatic efforts to break the cycle of violence and provide resources to victims and survivors of trauma. 


What Is Ball For Peace? 

- 3-on-3 Basketball Tournament
free for local students and open to all ages

- "Celebrity" Basketball Showcase
featuring teachers, coaches, and local personalities competing in games and skills competitions

- Community Resource Fair 
local organizations addressing violence and trauma share and connect resources with those who need them most


Who?

- The William Kellibrew Foundation, a D.C.-based nonprofit, hosts this event. 

- Student leaders from the Men of Code program (collectively known as the Knights of Adversity) help organize this event to fulfill their commitment to awareness and prevention of violence against women. The Knights of Adversity are selected members of the Friendship Collegiate Academy football team and have accepted their role as leaders in stopping sexual assault and domestic violence in their school and community.


Y(our) Impact

The summer should be a time of leisure and fun, but all too often, this is not the case for many youths. A lack of activities and resources to keep students engaged and an uptick in area violence and crime leaves many young people vulnerable. By contributing to this campaign, you are directly supporting a community event for students, strengthening measures to reduce neighborhood violence, and extending the reach of resources to those who need them most.

  

This is a fundraising community outreach event. The graph below demonstrates how the money will be used if we reach our $5500 online campaign goal. Because we wish to cover the majority of our event expenses through in-kind donations, this graph is subject to change. The more in-kind donations we receive from sponsors, the more money that will go towards program support. In-kind donations, ticket/registration sales, and other contributions may not be reflected on this page and help us reach our online campaign goal. We will share with supporters our total numbers and where it goes after the close of the event. Below is our best estimate:


What expenses must be covered for Ball For Peace? 

  • Free registration for local students
  • Transportation to the venue for students who need it
  • T-shirts, gift bags, and prizes
  • Food and beverage
  • Referees

What types of programs will your money support? 

  • Monthly men's and women's circles
  • Young male engagement at Capital City Public Charter School
  • Homer "Pete" Washington Community Fellowship


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Want to register a team or just attend? Click here: www.BallForPeace.eventbrite.com
  • Are you an organization that would like to take part in the resource fair? Email malik@thewkfoundation.org.
  • Would you like to volunteer at this event or in the future? Send an email with your name and contact information to volunteer@thewkfoundation.org


Come to our Happy Hour at The Mighty Pint! Or join us at Rita's for WKF Scoop Night! Funds go towards our Ball For Peace campaign!


Ball For Peace Happy Hour
Wednesday, July 9th @ 7:00pm
The Mighty Pint
1831 M Street NW
Washington, D.C.


WKF Scoop Night

Monday, July 7th, 5:00 - 8:00pm
Rita's Italian Ice
1014 H Street NE
Washington, D.C.


More About Our Sponsors...

  • Divine Chocolate
  • Frito-Lay
  • LLB Enterprises
  • Wallace Enterprises
  • WCK Consulting

Divine is the only fairtrade chocolate company which is owned by its cocoa farmers. 


More About Us...

 The 

 William Kellibrew         Foundation

The William Kellibrew Foundation is an advocate, bridge and community driven partner dedicated to breaking the cycles of violence and poverty. WKF harnesses and provides resources to both victims and similarly focused organizations through prevention, intervention, education and outreach. By sharing the stories of survivors we give voice to victims, raise community awareness and empower people working to rebuild their lives, families and communities. WKF is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt non-profit organization. 

WKF was founded in 2007 by two professors at the University of the District of Columbia in honor of their student, William C. Kellibrew IV. At the age of 10, William watched helplessly as his mother and twelve-year old brother were fatally shot at point-blank range in their living room by his mother’s former boyfriend.  His remarkable story of trauma, recovery, and healing is one that continues to inspire many across the World.

Trauma-informed care is central to WKF's mission. Meet the individuals who we reach through our work and the types of stories we encounter every day. Here is Deena Gray-Johnson from Schenectady, NY sharing her story.



More About Our Partners...

Men of Code

Presented by Becky’s Fund, in collaboration with the DC Coalition Against Domestic Violence (DCCADV), Positive Choice’s, Inc., and The William Kellibrew Foundation; Men of Code enlists men and boys as allies and proactive participants in the movement to end violence against women. An Engaging Men and Boys Grant Initiative, Men of Code utilizes training and mentorship that builds healthy relationships and leadership skills. Program participants will explore oppression; how it leads to intimate partner and sexual violence; bystander intervention including discussions about consent; and how to help someone who is in an abusive relationship. Men of Code is entering its second year at Friendship Collegiate Academy Public Charter School in Washington, D.C.

The William Kellibrew Foundation (WKF) is excited to host its second “Ball For Peace” Basketball Tournament & Showcase in collaboration with the Men of Code program and Friendship Collegiate Academy Football in Washington, D.C. This community event is an afternoon of fun dedicated to the awareness and prevention of gun violence, domestic violence, and sexual assault. This event brings together youth, educators, athletes, organizations, and community leaders.  All funds raised will support the event and WKF’s ongoing programmatic efforts to break the cycle of violence and provide resources to victims and survivors of trauma. What Is Ball For Peace? 
- 3-on-3 Basketball Tournamentfree for local students and open to all ages

- "Celebrity" Basketball Showcasefeaturing teachers, coaches, and local personalities competing in games and skills competitions

- Community Resource Fair local organizations addressing violence and trauma share and connect resources with those who need them most

story:
Short Summary

Hi we are Dwayne and Sue Lowdermilk owners of Frugie Beef. We have been hard at work for 3 years finalizing our pilot project. We also designed our certified feeding stands program.

 We may not be the most polished in our video but we are having fun being back to basics and growing a sustainable business.

Seeking   a change to go back to my passions as a youth, simple farming, great beef and easy 1-2 -3 steps. We have started up and ran a number of successful businesses over  the last 40 years and are very excited about Frugie beef being our best yet.

Frugie beef is based on utilizing unused farmland and giving it new life. By removing fruits and vegetables as  food waste from land fills that doesn't need to be disposed of. Lastly to give a beef product that is beyond Grass fed and Organic raised beef in its healthy content. “We raise Healthy Happy cattle.”  Our cattle
are raised from our own calves or purchased from reputable farms that meet our
requirement in our standards of ages, grass fed only, no anti-biotic, no
hormone, or steroid use, No Grain, No Corn, No Gluten...

Once cattle are under our standards program  using
ethical and humane protocol full of daily hands on care we place them on our
feeding program. We provide daily grazing with our selected hay and daily
feedings of fresh fruits and vegetables. We are an Eco friendly company keeping
500 + tons of fruits and vegetables out of landfills this last year and a half alone. We recycle all plastics and cardboard.

Some still have trouble believing cattle will eat fruits and vegetables but the
proof is in our meat from its powerful antioxidant-rich ingredients

Our bullet points for Frugie Beef.

-  Frugie beef has minimal fat content and the fruit and vegetable diet detox’s the meat and tissue of toxins. Frugie beef 3X leaner, tender, moist and provides quality meat taste and texture.

-  Daily feedings of fresh fruit and Vegetables maximize the intake to our cattle of all
natural vitamins, minerals and nutrients.

-  There is no grain fed into their diets giving us gluten free meat. “Grain Free Gluten Free”

-  We have not had any infections or unhealthy animals as they receive daily human care and feedings.

-  “We marinate our beef from the inside out.”

-  Our beef has a taste of its own, rich in flavour and tender with hints of vegetable and fruit flavors.

-  Our beef cooks much quicker as it is low  in fat. The juices in our meat when seared serve a delicious meat. Cooking tip- sear meat, high temp and lock in juices then lower heat, cook to desired doneness.

-  Frugie beef is high in heme iron very good for anemia suffers.

-  Frugie beef is high in conjugated linoleic acid - known as good CLA to read more. 
http://thyroid.about.com/cs/dietweightloss/a/cla.htm or
http://knh.nfobits.com/interesting-research/8-fats-good-and-bad-conjugated-linoleic-acid-cla.html

-  WE LOVE WHAT WE DO AND BRING PASSION TO OUR ARTISANAL HEALTHY CHOICE BEEF. FRUGIE BEEF

-  “Wild game meat without the gamey taste.”

-  We are a specialized meat product and not available to high production services.   Our goal is to present to other cities and towns our certification standards and process.

-  We have our Frugie beef processed by a BC Certified Processor and cut and wrapped by our local Butcher. 

 Contributing to our campaign will allow us to scientifically test our beef as to why Frugie beef is beyond grass and Organic. Frugie beef (cattle) are fed fruit and vegetables daily for a maximum natural intake of Vitamins, Nutrients and Minerals. We want to test for all vitamin and nutrient content levels in our beef as well as the enzymes or protein enzymes of gluten if any in our beef. 

The second reason to contribute will help expansion of growth with equipment needs, marketing and sales growth in the health food market. Our clients who already realize the lower fat beef is good but also the health benefits of our beef.

We have had articles in The Globe and Mail  

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/food-trends/where-raising-beef-on-apples-and-herbs-is-truly-the-fruits-of-their-labours/article19201573/

Also Local Langley Times Newspaper as well as an up coming Article in the Western Producer.

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

We want to raise $25,000 to get our scientific testing done as well as purchase,  repair and improve our machinery needs.

$12,000 is to testing lab for our full request tests.

$8,000 for new sorting and grinding machines and repairs to vehicles to date.

$3,000 for information and awareness info re sales and marketing

$ 4,000 for gift rewards and mailing.

These gifts are a part of our business, plus we are able to send world wide. We wanted to ship meat but at this time there are too many issues to ship world wide.

A heart felt email, Our designed decal to display, Apron the true farm accessory, Tee shirt to show Frugie beefs identity, Sample packs of Frugie beef smoked products for ease of shipping by Windsor Quality Meats, 

Dirt Bag Chef best rub you will ever taste on Frugie beef, 

                                   

 A full report on our finding and interesting twists along our pilot project that has become a full time business. Lastly for those that see opportunity and want to seek a very rewarding fun and healthy business model. Please review our perks in detail.

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Your contributions will help a lot to celiac, allergen and health issues. This can prove a product can be fed healthy and produce a even healthier food product to humans seeking healthy options.

We raise healthy - happy cattle in a humane and ethical standard with a resource that would be landfill bound on lands that people want to see farming but to busy or incapable of farming themselves.

Our 3 year pilot project has proved great things for our clients health and wellness. We have made great strides in protecting our planet and reducing waste. Now we want the documented truth by science which verify our beliefs that we have the healthiest beef for the world.

 

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

The risk is we stay small in our 100,000 populous and keep our light under a cover and only supply to the clients we have. This is not possible as word is travelling fast in the health world how anemia and allergen suffers are receiving our beef. We want to share our healthy beef with you.

The Challenges are we only raise enough money to get 1/2 the scientific results we need to document our beliefs and our clients truths how they feel after eating our enriched beef. We are very grateful for any monies raised to prove our beef is beyond grass fed and organic.

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes its not about money but sharing opportunities to friends or those in need. So please open your lists of contacts to our site and pray for those that seek relief from chronic pain or discomfort from allergies to meat or needs for higher levels of nutritional ingredients in their diet.

Please send out the word about Frugie beef that is worth more than money and please review all of Indiegogo's opportunities to share this project.

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story: hello my name is Monique Cochran, I'm a mother of three. I recently finished school with a diploma in medical office management and currently looking for a job in that field. Since march I have been a Chicago lyft driver. My car was booted Sept 19th and towed the next day of my parking tickets. I have been on a payment plan and never missed a payment but I continued to get tickets because I recently got an apartment and my money went to my security deposit. I am asking for help because my car is my only income and I have to take care of my children and post rent and utilities. Please help

story:
Short Summary

Many people, including working families with children, retired seniors and individuals struggling to make ends meet cannot:

- get to a grocery store that is within a mile from their home

- buy fresh, local and healthy food at fair market prices

Also, many men living at the Good Samaritan Shelter have a difficult time finding employment and earning a living wage.

Nourish Phoenixville can change all of that.

Nourish Phoenixville is a mobile market that makes fresh, healthy and locally grown and produced foods available to everyone in our community.  Nourish Phoenixville makes it easy for people to eat fresh and local by meeting them where they are - at work, at school, at play and wherever they find health and spiritual wellness.

Nourish Phoenixville will hire shelter residents to work in the business.  These men will realize an increase in their self confidence as they learn valuable job skills and earn a living wage.

Nourish Phoenixville encourages people to "eat well and do good" by reinvesting in our local economy and helping Good Samaritan Shelter fulfill its mission to provide hope and dignity to men experiencing homelessness.  

What We Need 

We are seeking to raise $15,000 to help with the purchase of the truck, trailer and refrigeration units.

The Impact

Nourish Phoenixville will increase access to fresh, healthy and local foods for all Phoenixville area residents, especially those living in food deserts or who are homebound.

Nourish Phoenixville will provide men experiencing homelessness with a wage-earning job, work experience and a pathway to financial stability. 

Nourish Phoenixville will contribute to local economic development, community health and wellness and our region’s environmental sustainability. 

Nourish Phoenixville will demonstrate that nonprofit organizations can become more entrepreneurial and generate mission-related income to offset reliance on charitable contributions.

Risks & Challenges

Nourish Phoenixville has a professional business plan and is seeking capital for start-up costs. Like any social or business enterprise, the start-up phase is not predictable and success is not a guarantee. However, we will direct whatever funds we raise to launch the enterprise, even in incremental steps.

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
An Agrobiodiverse Oasis

    

The Biological Orchard and Gardens (the BOG) is a collaboration between students, staff, and academic specialists and programs at the University of California Davis (UC Davis) to create a 24,000 ft² biodiversity teaching landscape in the heart of campus. The current planning team is headed up by both UC Davis staff, alumni and students:

  • Kelly Torres, BOG Project Administration, UC Davis analyst

  • Ernesto Sandoval, BOG Site Administration, UC Davis Botanical Conservatory Director

  • Emily Dorrance, BOG Student Project Manager, UC Davis Student


Our project will feature an innovative orchard dedicated to teaching concepts of agrobiodiversity to students through heirloom California fruit varieties threatened with extinction. Adding to the diversity of our site are micro-plots that will consist of plants native to South Africa, the Mediterranean region, and California; these plots will demonstrate the diversity of plants native to the Mediterranean biome and will serve as an outdoor ecological laboratory directly supporting instruction in the university’s immensely popular Introduction to Biology course. In a book published by Smithsonian on Home Gardens and Agrobiodiversity, small-scale gardening is emphasized as an important provider of:

“microenvironments [...] that contain high levels of species diversity and may contain crop species or varieties of species different from those found in surrounding agroecosystems.”

This agrobiodiversity makes the BOG a valuable addition to the campus-wide transition towards sustainable landscaping which embraces lawn reduction and plantings more suitable for the teaching, outreach and research mission of the University. Once completed, the BOG will:

  • serve as a demonstration of and test site for plants and trees more suitable to the Central Valley region’s hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters, with a focus on drought tolerant plants less commonly available in the Sacramento Valley

  • Act as a living museum by preserving unique fruit varieties threatened by commercial extinction

  • serve as a teaching garden for multiple university courses and internships

The transformation of this underutilized and moribund section of the UC Davis campus began in April 2012. The planning team enhanced an initial undergraduate site concept to make the BOG available for visitors as well as UC Davis students to observe innovative usage of water-wise landscaping, as well as displays of uncommon flora. To create an engaging public garden, site grading and amendment, a proper low volume irrigation system, and accessible pathways are crucial additions to the site.  

Due to budget cuts, the university is unable to fund the BOG. The planning team actively researches funding opportunities, and we have received a few awards and bestowed gifts, however, money is still needed to continue implementing the project. 

The planning team's current mission is to fund and implement:

* The remaining portion of a proper irrigation system - $1,900

  -800' of 1/2" polyethylene tubing with in-line pressure compensating emitters  
  -1000' -1/2" polyethylene tubing to supply and connect the irrigation rings around each tree   
  -200 mesh micro-filtration and pressure regulators for each of the two valves
  -Connectors  
  -1/2" PVC piping for 30,000 sq ft

* A portion of the required plants - $ 500

* 40 fruit trees - $1,600

* Seating and tables - $ 700

* Paving materials - $ 300


This is where you come in! We need your help to attain the $5,000.00  to complete our project, and have created a number of perks to thank you for your generous support. All products  are handpicked by the BOG planning team to highlight the   BOG as:

      "a collaboration of talent, enthusiasm, endurance, perseverance, knowledge, skills and strength that keeps this project moving forward".

If a monetary donation isn't feasible, please help us spread the word to seek donations and fund our campaign. We thank you for your collaboration!


Dedication to Sustainability:

The BOG has a high potential for success because it is supported by an interdisciplinary planning team consisting of current and alumni UC Davis students as well as staff. Each team member provides a unique perspective to guarantee that the BOG will perform a variety of services to the community. The BOG supports an academic need, fulfills our campus mission toward environmental stewardship and sustainability, and blends landscapes in a unique display of Agrobiodiversity. It is attentive to the agricultural beginnings of UC Davis, while fitting securely into the new plan for campus landscaping. Once in place, the BOG orchard will become the first Slow Food Foundation for Biodiversity Ark of Taste Orchard in the nation, a fantastic opportunity for the University as a global leader in agricultural research.







Relevant literature citations
1. Arboretum Review: Special Edition December 2011-draft. UC Davis Arboretum and Public Garden: The Campus as a Portal for Growth and Engagement; Diane Cary, Communications Director
2. Agricultural & Natural Resources Cooperative Extension, Yolo County:
http://ceyolo.ucdavis.edu/files/52972.pdf
3. Environmental Horticulture in California, “Training young trees in Structure and Form”, Mario Moratorio: http://ucanr.org/sites/EH_RIC/newsletters/Vol4_No4_Fall_200037619.pdf
4. Backyard Orchard Culture methodology,
http://www.davewilson.com/homegrown/BOC_explained.html
5. Fatemeh Kazemi, Beecham, S., Gibbs, J., Streetscape biodiversity and the role of bioretention swales in an Australian urban environment, 2011, Landscape and Urban Planning, 139-148
6. P.G. Mackintosh, The development of higher urban life and the geographic imagination: beauty, art, and moral environmentalism in Toronto, 1900-1920, 2005, Journal of Historical Geography,
688-722
7. Julia Bartens, Wiseman, P. Eric, Smiley, E. Thomas, Stability of landscape trees in engineered and conventional urban soil mixes, 2010, Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 333-338
8. P.B. Eyzaguirre, Linares, O.F., Home Gardens and Agrobiodiversity, 2004, Smithsonian Books
9. Slow Food USA, Ark of Taste, https://www.slowfoodusa.org/ark-of-taste

story:
BriansBid is the most generous and sustainable product buyback service on the web! Our mission is to reduce the amount of waste that enters our landfills by keeping products in use as long as possible. Once products reach the end of their useful life, we make it our responsibility to recycle those products. Concurrently, we strive to offer users more money for the things they want to sell than any competitor. We are the only buyback/recommerce service that lets you quickly and easily sell or recycle almost anything. Our service is quick, honest, and stress-free. At BriansBid, we care about the planet and we care about YOU!

Starting April 1st, 2015, BriansBid will donate 2.5% of every purchase to our featured charity of the quarter!  

We aim to be the go-to online destination for people who want to quickly and easily sell or recycle almost anything for the best price! Help us raise $100,000 so we have ample funds to recover, distribute, and recycle used products. 

What is recommerce? Recommerce, also known as reverse commerce, or reverse trade, is the process of reselling used goods to merchants. The merchant then re-markets the goods, and the cycle repeats. Once a product reaches the end of its useful life, it is the responsibility of the recommercer to recycle the useless product. The recycled material is then used to produce new products. Think of it as a continuous cycle. New goods become used goods, used goods become reused goods, reused goods become recycled goods, and recycled goods become new goods. Recommerce is beneficial for the consumer, the merchant, and most importantly, the environment.

BriansBid is a start-up launched on August 19th, 2014 by two friends: Brian and Kristopher. Brian got his start in recommerce when he was still in school and began buying and selling books. Kristopher noticed that selling stuff online was way too complicated and time consuming. Together, they decided to create the ultimate recommerce service - BriansBid was born. 

Visit www.BriansBid.com for more info.

story:
Your Friendly Neighbourhood Flower Farmer

Hello!

My name is Killoran Moore and I am going to be an urban flower farmer.  

I want to take disused land here in Victoria, be it people's yards or vacant lots, and use it to grow cut flowers to then sell at market and through a subscription service.  Using low/no-till, organic methods and keeping beneficial insects in mind I will grow many varieties you just can't find unless grown locally.  Heirloom,  scented, delicate, interesting, all kinds of flowers, but most importantly - FRESH and LOCAL. But I need your help to turn my small cutting garden into something more.

Each year, we are importing more and more of our cut flowers in Canada, and, quite frankly, there is NO need for this.  In British Columbia there is so much variety in the flowers we can grow locally – the possibilities for shape, colour, form, texture, and perfume are endless.  Endless!

I want to do something I love, something that not only makes me happy, but others as well.  Growing flowers is it.  I want my flowers to be a celebration of the seasons.  I want to do my part to spread the word about why local flowers matter, why they're better, and what it means to support your community.  I want to grow and sell flowers that are safe for everyone, including the critters that want to eat them.


WHY FLOWERS?
I like flowers.  I've always liked flowers.  Most people do – flowers make you smile.

Last spring I had a beautiful baby boy.  He was perfect.  He also cried inconsolably – a lot.  Aside from being physically attached to me, the only thing that seemed to settle him down was being held in front of flowers.

That activated my love and appreciation for flowers.  I started reading about flowers, and I began to follow more and more florists on Instagram and Pinterest.  I learned that some of these florists were actually farmer-florists.  I was floored.  You can grow flowers.. for a living? 

Reading more about these farmer-florists led me to the Slow Flower movement, and a heightened awareness of the importance of locally-grown flowers.


People want, and are entitled, to know the origin of their flowers.  Most flowers sold in Canada are imported from Latin America, from countries that do not have the same strict regulations regarding pesticide use.  Bunches of flowers are dipped in large tubs of pesticide to prevent importing pests.  Other flowers are sprayed regularly.  Workers are exposed to these pesticides – no one should have to wear a mask when harvesting flowers.  And if workers wear masks around the flowers, why are you sticking your face right in them?

Unless you're buying locally grown flowers, the odds are not great that there will be any fragrance at all.  Flowers imported from thousands of miles away, as most of our flowers are, don't have the luxury of having scent.  Fragrance is costly for a plant and shortens its life, especially out of water, and by the time these flowers get to you, they've been out of water for around two weeks. That's what they're bred for - uniformity and a long lifespan so they can make it to consumers.

Also, flowers are a valuable crop that can be grown on small parcels of land that aren't necessarily ideal for food production, such as disused industrial lots. Cities are full of these little pockets of brown-space – why not put them to use, and make things more beautiful in the process?

What We Need, What You Get, & What's Next

The amount of funding I am asking for is the minimum needed to get started.  I need to expand my small cutting garden by about 450 square feet and it's going to be a lot of work.  Let's break it down, y'all:

  • Beds - This includes: materials ($40 x 11 beds), fill ($35/yd x 11-12 + delivery fee), and amendments (organic fertilizer, lime, bone meal $75) = $965
  • Irrigation - This is for an irrigation kit, extra tubing and connectors = $150
  • Tools & Supplies - I don't have any of my own! Wheelbarrow ($115.. the one you're seeing in the photos doesn't have a bottom), various tools ($80.. shovel, hoe, garden fork, trowel, snippers), soil blockers and bins ($70), wire and netting ($100), labels ($10) = $375
  • Transport & Market Needs - I don't drive and want to keep my environmental impact low.  I need a bike and trailer ($300) to get to the market as well as tables, a canopy, and a sign ($150). = $450
  • Flowers - I still have some seed from my cutting garden, but I need to purchase more in order to fill the beds with a wider range of blooms and keep them in flower all season long = $135
  • Miscellaneous - This includes things like materials for making potting mix ($35), building a propagation table and light rig ($75), flower food, card stock, and a smidge extra in case I've forgotten something (you know how it goes), = $180
  • Fees - This includes market vendor fees ($35), domain, business registration and name fees ($80), and IndieGoGo fees = $250


PERKS
My husband is an illustrator and has graciously agreed to help me out with perks! Wahoo! He will be doing some nice botanical illustrations as well as illustrations of beneficial insects.  These will then be available at different perk levels as sets of greeting cards or art prints.
I will be making pressed flower bookmarks and monograms, which would look lovely framed.  


Important notes:
  • Every person who supports this campaign will have their first name/screen-name/pseudonym/whatever added to a 'Thank You' page on the future website/blog. If you do not want your name on the list, let me know!
  • If you choose a perk involving either a monogram or an illustrated card/print, be sure to leave us your email so we can contact you about your initial and choice of cards/print.  You can contact honeylashflowerfarms@gmail.com .
  • I have set a date of next year for many of the perks as I want to allow plenty of time to prepare and send them.  Ideally, they would be out before the deadline (except the flower subscription and pick-your-own).
Why Fixed Funding
I chose fixed funding (I must meet my goal or I get nothing) because that's the only way I'd be able to fulfill all the perks and get started.  For example: If I raised only half the funds but the flower subs were claimed - I wouldn't be able to fill that perk!
If I don't meet my goal, that is obviously a sign that I need to regroup, re-evaluate my plan/budget, and try again.  Worst case scenario, I'll apply for a community micro-loan (which has 10% interest - yikes!).
If I manage to go beyond my goal, that money will go toward building more beds, getting more plants, attending a local farmer's workshop where I can learn from another person.. in person.. and hopefully gain some new skills.  Everything will go toward building up the flower farm.

WHAT'S NEXT


Being able to start up with no debt will allow me to put money earned toward growing my business by: attending intensives and workshops to learn more about flower farming and floristry, expanding the number of plots being farmed (I would like to have two more yards/lots in use by summer), opening up more spaces for flower subscription clients, saving for my own land, etc.

When people buy from local growers and makers, supporting small businesses, it keeps money in the community.  In the future I want to be able to pay-it-forward and show the same support you [hopefully] want to show me.  I'm not sure what form that will take yet, but I'm workin' on it.

And on a more personal level.. I won't always have to leave my family for an eight hour work day somewhere else, doing something I don't enjoy.  My son will get to grow up knowing that work can be something that brings you joy and fulfilment.

Risks & Challenges

Nature.  Farming on any scale (even when it's gardening) has risks.  Number one is nature - we are at the mercy of the elements.  I can't predict when spring will start a whole month early, or when there'll be no rain for a month.  All I can do is go with it,  figure something out, and learn from it.

Pests and disease are another issue.  As I'll be using organic methods, I will not be spraying your flowers with any harmful pesticides.  The plus side of having a small-scale operation is that the crop size is more manageable.

Other Ways You Can Help

No disposable income? That's A-OK - I understand! You don't have to help financially:

  • SPREAD THE WORD share this campaign - on Facebook, Tumblr, Instagram, via email.  Any way you can spread the word has immeasurable value!
  • Like the Facebook page, follow on Instagram (@honeylashflowerfarm), stay tuned for updates!
  • Ask for local flowers at your local florist, grocer, corner store, whatever.  Support local growers!

And that's all there is to it.

Links of interest:

Agriculture report: 

Statistical Overview of the Canadian Ornamental Industry - 2013

Global article: Where are your Valentine's roses from?

For Americans who want to source their flowers locally: Slow Flowers - has a searchable directory!

And on a more personal level.. I won't always have to leave my family for an eight hour work day somewhere else, doing something I don't enjoy.  My son will get to grow up knowing that work can be something that brings you joy and fulfilment.



  Risks & Challenges Nature.  Farming on any scale (even when it's gardening) has risks.  Number one is nature - we are at the mercy of the elements.  I can't predict when spring will start a whole month early, or when there'll be no rain for a month.  All I can do is go with it,  figure something out, and learn from it.Pests and disease are another issue.  As I'll be using organic methods, I will not be spraying your flowers with any harmful pesticides.  The plus side of having a small-scale operation is that the crop size is more manageable.

   Other Ways You Can Help No disposable income? That's A-OK - I understand! You don't have to help financially:  
SPREAD THE WORD share this campaign - on Facebook, Tumblr, Instagram, via email.  Any way you can spread the word has immeasurable value!
Like the Facebook page, follow on Instagram (@honeylashflowerfarm), stay tuned for updates! Ask for local flowers at your local florist, grocer, corner store, whatever.  Support local growers!   And that's all there is to it.Links of interest:Agriculture report: Statistical Overview of the Canadian Ornamental Industry - 2013Global article: Where are your Valentine's roses from?For Americans who want to source their flowers locally: Slow Flowers - has a searchable directory!

story:
Je m’appelle Patrick Souop, né à Bafoussam le 5 avril 1991, au coeur de la région de l'Ouest au Cameroun, marquée par la culture Bamiléké. Je suis issu d’une famille agricole d'un petit village avec des petits revenus et des parents ayant peu fréquenté l’école. J’ai passé avec succès le bac en sciences mathématiques, et j’ai décidé de poursuivre mes études plutôt que de fonder une famille.

Mon objectif est de réaliser mon rêve de devenir pilote de ligne, un métier que j’ai choisi du plus profond de mon cœur depuis que j’ai 5 ans. Si je ne peux pas réaliser mon rêve, j’aimerais obtenir un diplôme d’ingénieur ou un Master dans ce secteur.

Je me suis donc inscrit en faculté de Sciences physiques à l’université de Dschang. Je dois actuellement financer seul cette initiative : logement, cours, nourriture… J’ai réussi à me débrouiller pour passer les première et deuxième années. Si je devais résumer ma situation avec un terme beaucoup plus utilisé en physique, ce donne alors ceci : un étudiant isolé.

Sans détailler toutes les galères par lesquelles je suis passé, je me suis alors demandé : comment pourrais-je plus facilement financer mes études ? J’ai vu que la photocopie des cours et des TD faisaient dépenser beaucoup les étudiants. Avoir une photocopieuse permettrait alors de réduire ces frais et de gagner un peu d’argent en rendant service aux autres étudiants de la fac, à un prix leur permettant également de diminuer leurs frais de photocopie.

J’ai discuté avec des personnes qui avaient des photocopieuses : avec une machine neuve et un lieu de vente à proximité de la fac l’activité se trouve très rentable. En la disposant dans ma chambre, qui ferme à clé, pas besoin de louer un local, je n’aurai que l’encre à payer, et je serai bien place… Mais une photocopieuse neuve vaut 600 000 FCFA ( 916€), sans compter le transport depuis le port de Douala (40 000 FCFA) ! Arrivant à peine à payer ma nourriture, je devais penser à autre chose de concret plutôt que de rester dans l’abstraction. J’ai alors pensé à un ami français, Maxime Plat, que j’ai connu en stage dans mon village (il logeait chez ma mère) et qui m’a toujours soutenu dans ma démarche. Il m’a conseillé de me tourner vers le financement participatif ! Même si je ne parviens pas à tout financer par cette voie, les fonds récoltés me permettront d’accéder à un micro-crédit, actuellement inaccessible faute d'apport personnel ou de garanties suffisantes aux yeux des caisses de micro-crédit que j'ai rencontré.

Si je rêve de voyages et de découverte, j'aime ma culture Bamiléké et j'aime la faire partager. C'est une culture riche et qui a réussi à rester vivante et évoluer jusqu'à aujourd'hui. Je vous la ferai partager avec grand plaisir au travers des contreparties de vos dons si précieux, malgré les difficultés d'acheminement jusqu'à chez vous : chapeaux, bijoux, masques, instruments de musique, sacs artisanaux, habits et objets de cérémonies bamilékés. Pour les plus généreux et curieux d'entre vous, nous vous proposons même nos contacts et bonnes adresses pour venir découvrir cette région magnifique !

    Si toutefois vous ne pouvez pas contribuer mais que mon projet vous intéresse, en parler autour de vous et sur les réseaux sociaux sera une contribution toute aussi précieuse !

    Quel est l’intérêt du projet ?

    Pour moi :

    • Il réduit mes frais de photocopie

    • Il me procure des rentrées d’argent régulières et à court-terme

    • Cela me prend peu de temps, d’effort physique et ai peu risquée (même par rapport au vol), ce qui est très compatible avec les études

    Pour les autres étudiants :

    • J’offrirai des photocopies à un meilleur prix par rapport aux autres vendeurs qui profitent de leur statut et de leur petit nombre (15 FCFA au lieu de 20)

    • Je serai plus accessible pour les étudiants car sur le campus même (le prix des transports étant élevés par rapport à nos moyens)

    Quelles sont les forces du projet ?

    • Des personnes de ma famille peuvent me fournir les contacts adéquats pour acheter une photocopieuse fiable

    • Mon service sera vraiment attractif par rapport aux autres pour les étudiants

    • Dschang est la deuxième ville universitaire du Cameroun, après Yaoundé la capitale

    Quels sont les risques liés au projet

    • vol ou dégradation de la photocopieuse : il sera fortement atténué car elle sera dans ma chambre, que je peux verrouiller, lorsque je n'y serais pas pour offrir mes services

    • désintérêt des étudiants : Même avec un prix 25 % inférieur à 15 FCFA, mon activité reste rentable car je peux trouver de l'encre bon marché

    Budget pour démarrer le projet : 1826€ dont

    • Photocopieuse : 915€
    • Transport du port de Douala à Dschang : 60€
    • Encre pour commencer : 50€
    • Papier pour commencer : 90€
    • Contreparties (frais d'acheminement inclus) : 625€
    • Service offert par Indiegogo : 85€

    Si vous souhaitez avoir plus de détails sur le projet, contactez mon ami Maxime, qui m'a aidé à monter le projet et à le gérer (envoi des contreparties, transfert des dons). De tout cœur, merci pour votre aide.

    Patrick Souop Feussi
